FacilityName: Arctic Glacier Premium Ice - Carson, CA

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Arctic Glacier Premium Ice management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Arctic Glacier Premium Ice's safety and environmental policies are administered by the Plant Engineer, who conducts periodic inspections of the facility to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs, including the PSM/RMP/CalARP Program.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Arctic Glacier Premium Ice facility is located at 17011 South Central Avenue in Carson, California. The facility is less than a mile north of Highway 91.

The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban, surrounded by other commercial facilities. The regulated material present at the facility and the focus of this study is anhydrous ammonia. The facility uses approximately 22,000 pounds of ammonia as a refrigerant within a closed system. The system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for ice production and its storage. Typical operating conditions range from 10 psig on the low pressure side of the system to 165 psig on the high side.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Arctic Glacier Premium Ice ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. For example, the facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation. The facility conducts preventative maintenance and any necessary minor repairs in house, but an outside contractor is hired for major repa

irs or maintenance. The facility including the ammonia system was designed and constructed in accordance with the applicable building codes and standards at the time of construction These safety features include ammonia sensors in the engine room. In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine room and just outside of the engine room (condensers). All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves. All of the relief valves are tied into a common relief header that vent to the Diffusion Tank.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.

The release must have caused at least one of the following:



? On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

? Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history conducted during the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study on November 20, 2019, there have been no releases of ammonia that meet this criteria in the past five years (November 2014 - November 2019). In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Arctic Glacier Premium Icefacility has an emergency response plan in effect. The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP/CalARP document. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1.) To save lives.

2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.

3.) To protect the environment.

4.) To minimize property damage.

The operator of the facility maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators

for the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan

was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations. In case of an ammonia emergency, the facility plans to evacuate all employees and contractors and activate the facility's response plan to respond to the situation. If necessary, they will alert the local emergency responders (fire department) for assistance. The facility plans to coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazards Analysis, conducted on November 20, 2019, including a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study and a Facility Inspection, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Arctic Glacier Premium Ice facility. The Arctic Glacier Premium Ice safety committee is planning to complete several items over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. These changes include the following items:

1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
